It uses a curious dice-rolling mechanism that allows players to try to place their fly balls, ground balls, and bunts on a spot of the field least covered by opposing fielders. Strategy comes into play on offense in strategically allocating dice for a fly ball; on defense with positioning fielders to optimally cover the field.

No production date is given, but one of the Sid Sackson collection copies of this game was marked as being acquired in 1983.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Knock-Out
description:
Add three numbers together to make a total. Then use your best thinking skills to break that total into its parts to knock your opponents off the board while capturing numbers for yourself! From the mathematically challenged to the mathematically gifted, KNOCK-OUT!, with its multi-leveled play, is guaranteed to make math fun again!

http://www.educationallearninggames.com/how-to-play-muggins-...
publishers: LEI Éditions Canada, Old Fashioned Products, Inc.

name: Monkey Trouble
description:
A huge catastrophe has happened during the reception that the Countess organized in her garden! Koko the little monkey has escaped and stolen panties and other sexy underwear from the drying line. Here he is, giving them to the guests who are shocked by this dreadful vision !

The Countess is beside herself and orders her servant to quickly do something otherwise he will be fired. But Alfred is too old to catch the monkey ! So he decides to ask the many participants to go into the living room after he gets back the panties that are being given out Koko. Hopefully when he eventually catches Koko, he will be able to get several pairs of underwear back simultaneously. Anyway he’ll have to make sure that at 5 o’clock, no more guest still has a piece of underwear in hand or he loses his job.

name: The Big Match Football Game
description: Game of Australian Rules Football. The Big Match Football Game from 1991 closely simulates the real thing. Role the dice and move the football down the field by hand or foot. Marks are contested, scores kicked, tackles laid, free kicks given, ball-ups ruled, reports made etc.. Tackle cards and play cards provide the umpires decision on contests.

name: Midway
description:
This is a Japanese wargame on the Battle of Midway, 1942.

Published as one of the Series: SS (Sho-Kikaku) in 1990.

name: The Driving Test
description:
The Game that helps you pass your test.

The Driving Test has been developed in association with The Driving Standards Agency - the official body that sets all driving examinations and tests all learner drivers. So, every time you play it you will learn more of the theory of driving and road safety - essential if you are going to get rid of those big red 'L' plates.

name: Coffee Break
description:
From the back of box:

"In Coffee Break, challenge your co-workers to a contest of time management, competing to take the most coffee breaks during a day of work. To win, work hard and avoid goofing off, being sure to stay one step ahead of the boss.

So relax, grab a cup of coffee and experience a whole new kind of coffee break. And if people complain, remind them that its all in a day's work."

Game includes:
a game board
50 cards
40 coffee break markers
5 pawns
rules
a Coffee Break mug

Players take turns drawing and playing cards to move pawn ahead on the board which is divided into the hours of the work day. Players have the option of playing a card or taking a "coffee break" and sitting for a turn while collecting a chit. Cards can move a player forwards or move back another player. Every turn the Boss is moved one space. If the Boss catches up with you you lose a coffee break. Player to reach the end of the work day with the most coffee breaks wins.

Game only available from website www.gluckgames.com

name: Snake Snack
description:
The game is played on board with 4 snakes biting each others tails. There are 11-14 spots on each snake. Players take turns rolling the die and moving one of their 4 counters. When your counter lands in front of a snakes mouth, all counters standing on a spot of the same color as the counters color, is eaten and out of the game. Last player with counters in the game wins.

Found in a book called: "John Astrop's Ghastly Games" - "12 Sinister Board Games Invented Designed and Drawn for Your Pleasure" (Patrick Hardy Books, London, 1st edition 1983 / Delacorte Press, New York, 1st USA Printing 1983. Has 24 pages, 10"x14", includes 12 games, a.o.: Snake Snack, Ugly Mug, Dracula's Blood, Hades, Doom Castle, Clone, Boogey House, Tubes, Sharks, Germs, Swamp and Spider.

name: Star Corps: Call to Battle
description:
This is a game of small unit actions set in the near future. Designed for quickly and simply introducing new players to table top miniature battles. D6 based with simple armor and weapons charts and straight forward combat resolution. The game was designed around Lance & Laser's miniature range of the same name.

http://www.teamfrog.com/fig-sc.htm
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Wargame
publishers: Lance and Laser Models, Inc., Team Frog Studios

name: Little Polar Bear Memory Game
description:
The Little Polar Bear Memory is based on the traditional game of memory and can be played that way, with players turning over cards, two at a time, trying to find as many matched pairs as possible through luck or by remembering the location of the cards.
The game has 30 regular picture pairs and 12 special Little Polar Bear cards. This addition makes five variations of the traditional game possible. Some of these are easier to play; some are more challenging and difficult.

name: Behind Every Good Man
description:
From the KenMGames website:

"Write what you know" I am told. Well, here is the result. A "funny-if-it-were-not-so-true" kind of card game. The hand you are dealt, for good or for bad, is your man. It's your job to try and make something out of him. Or at least change him enough that you won't be embarrassed taking him out once in a while. Yes, Behind Every Good Man is one TIRED and FRUSTRATED woman! Included are some great variations like "Nobody's Perfect!" "The Dating Scene" and "Blind Date!"

name: Petting Zoo Gangsta
description:
Petting Zoo Gangsta is a web published game available at: http://www.interactivitiesink.com/cardgames/index.html
The object of this game is to be the last one standing at the petting zoo. You roll a die to see what animal you love and roll again to see what animal you fear (this may be the same animal) then you randomly place the animals on a checkerboard. Then you roll a die for movement and roll again for shooting your gun at other players and animals. Last one standing wins.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Wall of Goosh
description:
A wicked witch has just transformed you and your friends into squishy colorful frogs and placed you in a Room of Doom! As you gaze across the room, you see that the far wall is moving closer and closer!
Make it to one of the exits and you have a chance to escape, fail and the wall will mash you into a pile of senseless GOOSH!
The Wall of Goosh is a board game for 2 to 7 players. Colorful frog playing pieces - 3D Wall - Quick to learn, great for crazy game play!
A great little game for quick and fun play. The Wall of Goosh - from Obligatory Inn Press. The Innkeeper sends you best wishes for a memorable stay and some good gaming.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Perfect Union
description:
"Following the American Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776, the Thirteen Colonies engaged the British forces in the Revolutionary War. After the war ended, representatives from the colonies met to ratify the U.S. Constitution and select a leader. In Perfect Union, it is your task to influence the vote in each of the colonies so that your candidate gets elected president."

The game is played over seven rounds, with each player playing a single card from a fixed set each round. All the cards played in a round must be different. Most of the cards allow the player to place a certain number of pieces on the board, divided among the colonies as they wish. Two of the cards allow players to move already-placed pieces.

At the end of the game each colony is assessed and the player with the most pieces in each wins its votes. If there's a tie the colony is temporarily ignored. If no player reaches 22 votes the lowest player's pieces are removed from the board and everything is re-assessed.

The rules give no maximum number of players, but six seems reasonable.

name: Berchtesgaden: The Alpine Redoubt
description:
This is a small game--60 counters, a hex map less than a letter-sized piece of paper--depicting a "What If?" scenario from WW2. In this game, the Allies launch an attack on a (never-built in reality) last-ditch defensive line high in the Alps. The Allies have overwhelming numerical superiority; the only hope for the Germans is to stave off elimination long enough to win a separate peace with the West.

(Adapted from the introduction to the rules, which appeared in Panzerschreck Magazine 4.)

name: Tornado
description:
A delightful twist on the standard race around the board theme. Tornado adds spice with twisters that throw players across the board. Based on best-selling children's author John Erickson's "Hank the Cowdog", game includes an audio tape of the story of Hank the Cowdog and his friends.

Hank the Cowdog fans rejoice! The wildest Race and Chase GAME ever!

It's a race to be the first to get your three "characters" from the start to the finish. But watch out, your opponent is chasing you and may send you back to the start. And landing on a tornado space can send you flying in any direction!The only safe place is a finish space. And in this fast paced game it's truly, never over until it's over!

You can even take the TORNADO game with you on the road! Everything can be stored inside the folding plastic game board!

Hear "Drover's Tornado Safety Song." Drover's funny song is included on your free 30 minute cassette tape from Hank's award winning audio, The Case of the Swirling Killer Tornado.

Includes:

1 plastic playing board
12 "characters"
tornado spinner
instructions
For 2-4 players -Ages 5+
The game board opens to a full 8.5 by 8.5 inches!
publishers: Maverick Publishing LLC, Reveal Entertainment, Inc.

name: Vokabo
description:
Roughly translated from Synes Ernst's description on the Spiel des Jahres site:

The novelty in this game lies in the combination of word or letter play with Rummikub-like mechanics. With "Vokabo" the goals is to lay out 15 letter cards according to certain rules as rapidly as possible. One needs at least 20 points for the first laying out, and the words must be formed from at least three letters. When laying out one may extend existing words or change them to new words. In contrast to "Scrabble", which develops slowly, the game situation changes constantly in "Vokabo". Flexibility is required as well as constant thought.

name: The Peoria Game
description: This looks like a Monopoly variant set in Peoria, Illinois, using actual business names from that city.

name: High Spirits with Calvin and the Colonel
description:
This was Sid Sackson's first professionally-published game, later reworked into "Das Super-Blatt" and "Buried Treasure." It was a tie-in to a short-lived children's cartoon show (which was based on the Amos & Andy radio and TV shows), with the card suits corresponding to characters from the cartoon.

The game involved picking the top cards from stacks of overlapped face-up cards (so you could see what choices your pick would free up later), and scoring points thereby. The other catch is that the cards have different values in different rounds of the game, so there are a number of timing issues involved.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Plymouth Challenge
description:
PLYMOUTH CHALLENGE is a monopoly style board game developed by the Plymouth (UK) YMCA to generate funds for its activities.

Players progress around the board as a result of the roll of 2D6. When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company (there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

Players landing on companies that are already owned must pay to visit, with the payment due being based on how many shares are owned in that particular company and in the other two companies in the same color series. Since shares can be owned by two different players both may demand payment from a visitor.

Certain squares on the board require the drawing of a Chance card which normally result in income being received from or paid to the bank.

The “New Share Quotations” square results in the changing of share prices for some of the blocks of companies. This will result in players losing or gaining money on the shares that they own. It also requires players to put up one of their shares for auction thereby permitting players to trade in shares.

The game can be ended in three ways, which should be decided before the game starts:
- After a set time.
- When the first player becomes bankrupt.
- When all but one player has gone bankrupt.

At the end of the game the money is counted and shares are valued at whatever is the then current rate. The player with the greatest assets is declared the winner.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Death Derby: The Demolition Card Game
description:
Prepare yourself to enter the Death Derby Tournament -- the hardly collectible card game of over-the-top vehicular combat where machine guns roar, missiles light up the sky, and a carton of eggs can stop a tank. Choose one of ten stock vehicles or create your own. Then begin your rampage by gathering weapons and upgrading your vehicle while blasting opponents and overcoming battlefield hazards!

Death Derby was designed with simplicity in mind. The rules are easy to learn and game play is fast and fun. Three different sets of playing cards are included. Each needs to be printed, cut, separated, and then compiled into a complete deck.

This was created by Politically Incorrect Games before they changed their imprint name to Precis Intermedia.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Fighting, Humor

name: The Guildford Game
description:
THE GUILDFORD GAME is one of a series of Monopoly style board game developed by local YMCAs in the UK to generate funds for their activities. The games in the series are essentially the same, but as in the different versions of Monopoly, the board and the businesses are specifically themed to the town or city represented in the title - in this case Guildford some 30 miles South West of London.

Players progress around the board as a result of the roll of 2D6. When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company (there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

Players landing on companies that are already owned must pay to visit, with the payment due being based on how many shares are owned in that particular company and in the other two companies in the same colour series. Since shares can be owned by two different players both may demand payment from a visitor.

Certain squares on the board require the drawing of a Chance card which normally result in income being received from or paid to the bank.

The “New Share Quotations” square results in the changing of share prices for some of the blocks of companies. This will result in players losing or gaining money on the shares that they own. It also requires players to put up one of their shares for auction thereby permitting players to trade in shares.

The game can be ended in three ways, which should be decided before the game starts:
- After a set time.
- When the first player becomes bankrupt.
- When all but one player has gone bankrupt.

At the end of the game the money is counted and shares are valued at whatever is the then current rate. The player with the greatest assets is declared the winner.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Austerlitz: December 1805
description:
The Battle of Austerlitz was fought on December 2, 1805. Napoléon's Grand Armée concluded a brilliant campaign by defeating a combined force of Russian and Austrian troops. Napoleon lured the two allies to their destruction by feigning weakness, then crushing their hasty advance with a left wing envelopment. It is considered Napoléon's greatest victory.

Designed by Bruce McFarlane, Austerlitz modifies the game system of in Gettysburg: Badges of Courage to reflect Napoléonic combat. It can be played with two or three players.

name: Battlestations
description: Miniatures rules for naval combat from 1930 to 1945. Has beginner's and advanced rules, plus ship data.
categories: Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame, World War II

name: Monopoly: Japan
description: The colour sets to collect are major cities around Japan. Instead of railway stations, there are complete railways. This seems to be a fairly straight translation of the more well-known game.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Off to See the Wizard
description:
Off to See the Wizard Game - based on the animated TV series.

Players assume the roles of Dorothy and her friends, competing with each other, trying to capture the Witch and bring her to the Wizard.

The Game is played in two parts. The first part consists of chasing and capturing the Witch.

Player pieces travel on red circles and the Witch disc travels on yellow triangles. If a player piece and the Witch disc coincide on a black square the player captures the Witch.

The second part is getting the Witch to the Wizard.

The player with the Witch disc tries to get it to the Wizard while chased by the other players.

The Witch may exchange hands several times before one player succeeds in getting her to the Wizard to win the game.
categories: Dice, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based, Racing
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Gist
description:
Gist is a card game of combing colors to make other colors.
Players try to take the most cards. The deck is comprised of only six different types of cards: magenta, red, yellow, green, cyan and blue. Each round a player starts with 6 dealt cards, and may do one of four actions: Show, Activate, Combine and Take. To show a card a player takes a card out of is hand and places it on the table in front of him, it still belongs to him. To activate, take a show card and place it in the center of the table, which now belongs to all. To Combine, a player may take one card from his hand and combine it with one of his show cards, combine two of his show cards, combine one of his show cards with an active card, or two active cards. Only cards whose colors are one color apart on the color wheel may be combined. For example red and blue makes magenta, and blue and cyan makes green. To Take cards, a player takes one of his show cards (or a combination as if it were the combined color) and an active card, (or combination) and puts them aside for scoring at the end of the round. To take, the colors must be exactly opposite on the color wheel, for example a blue show card (or magenta, cyan combination) takes yellow active card (or red, green combination).

Advanced rules allow combining more than two cards to make combinations, thus yellow combined with a blue/red combination (as if it were magenta) makes red.

Although the number of players is stated as 2 to 6, there is no five player version. Two decks of 36 cards, six of each color come with the game, one deck is used for 2 or 3 players, both are used for 4 or 6 players.

name: Goldrausch Kalifornien 1849-53
description: 36 Claim tiles are mixed and placed face down throughout the board. Pioneers borrow money to search for gold hoping to beat the interest on their loans. Stake claims and wash gold, but look out for sandbars. Try to get as many claims as possible in hopes to strike it rich with nuggets. First to $20,000 (with no debts) wins. Beware Gold Fever!

name: Diamond Chess
description: Diamond Chess is an elegant variation of the classic game. The playing surface is composed of 98 alternating black and white triangles, a shape that provides for new and intriguing movements. The pieces move analogous with their counterparts in conventional chess, although familiarity with that game is not necessary to understand and enjoy Diamond Chess.
publishers: Mind Force Games, Think Tank Games

name: Holper Stolper
description:
Description by the publisher:

The animal scientist Bumby Stumble (Holper Stolper) has purchased new provisions and is on his way back to the research station. The most arduous part of the track is still in front of him: he has to drive the jeep with the precious load right through the rough jungle. That will only be possible if he watches carefully all the way and can avoid the potholes.

name: Nuke Your Neighbor
description:
2-4 player (or 8 players in 4 teams of 2) strategy game played on a large square grid. The object of the game is to be the last player with playing pieces on the gameboard. “Survival is the most important strategy.”

Each player has two minutes to complete their turn, which is done by rolling two die. If they roll doubles, they draw a card after moving their pieces and roll again. Cards are played before rolling, after rolling doubles or immediately depending on the card.
As the game progresses and players are down to their last piece and it is placed in a shelter other than his/her own, they have the option of remaining there and continue or forfeit their roll and return to their own shelter. Play continues until one player remains with his/her pieces.

Note: Game is for 2 to 4 players, but the instructions provide rules for 8 players (4 teams of 2 players)
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Team-Based Game

name: Lotto: The Fantasy Game
description:
Play commences in the Lotto Shop, players move around the board in a clockwise direction landing on squares that display various game play actions.

The object of each player is to mark off the six numbers selected and circled on their Lotto Entry Coupon.

As each player reaches this point in the game, they move directly to the Lotto Shop, collect $1,000,000, then select and circle another six numbers on a new Lotto Entry Coupon, and wait for their next turn to continue playing Lotto.
the action continues until the first player has won or purchased all six Fantasy Card, Winning Lotto.

Fantasy cards consist of Tropical Islands, Luxury Boat, Shopping Spree, Luxury Mansion, Luxury Car, Overseas Holiday.

name: Chaos in the Henhouse
description:
From the instructions: There is chaos in the henhouse – the clumsy rooster has rolled all the eggs onto the floor of the hayloft, and the hen’s nests are empty. Now al the eggs have to put back into the nests quickly. If you’re lucky the little mouse will help you, but be careful that the rooster doesn’t stumble through your nest.
A fun colour and memory game.

The game contains a large (approx. 40 cm), colourful gameboard illustrated by Hermien Stellmacher. The board has 20 recessed spaces to hold the wooden eggs (5 each of 4 colours) and 4 matching hen's nests with coloured spaces for each egg. There is a die showing 1 space of each colour, plus 1 mouse and 1 rooster. The rules detail 2 versions:
1. A straight memory version where the aim is to gather the 5 eggs in your colour before the other players.
2. A version where the winner is the first player to gather 5 eggs in any colour where you keep the egg if you match the colour rolled on the die. A mouse rolled on the die gives you an extra egg, a rooster returns an egg from your nest to the henhouse floor.

name: Word Challenge
description:
Aim: To find a secretly selected word (Code Word) of six or more letters.

Select a word master by means of each player rolling the eight dice in turn. The player with the greatest number of vowel letters appearing (ie A E I O U) will be the first Word Master.

The Word Master secretly writes the code word on a piece of paper. The word must be kept face down in front of him during play. The word selected must have six or more letters and must be correctly spelled. The Word Master must inform all players the number of letters in the Code Word.
All other players take a Word Challenge Analysis Sheet. The player ot the left of the Word Master then rolls the dice and selects a maximum of any three letters showing from the eight dice and writes such letters in pencil on his Analysis Sheet.
The Analysis Sheet is then handed to the Master who must mark the sheet in the following manner:
If a chosen letter appears in the code word the Word Master leaves it untouched.
If a chosen letter does not appear in the Code Word the master must put a cross through it. Play then passes to the next player.

name: Prince of Tennis TCG
description:
In the Prince of Tennis Trading Card Game you can play either a singles game or a doubles game. In addition, you don't have to play with the characters teams shown in the anime/manga series so you can mix up players to your liking.

Object of the Game:
You play with a deck composed of the cards you like (players, techniques, etc.). The card game is kinda like player real tennis. You use different strokes and moves to win the game. The player that score 4 points first wins the game (in real tennis it's counted 15,30,40,game). Winning the point is determine by the cards you play like using a power serve or smash ace.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Comic Book / Strip, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Sports

name: Rimboe-Cross
description:
This game portrays a race across the African continent.

Each player is racing in a jeep across the African steppes and is trying to plant trees. In order for the tree to survive, you have to carefully manage your water supply. You also bring 2 of 4 different objects that can protect you against the hazards of the wild so that you don't lose any time. But watch out - behind your back your opponent may destroy your trees or steal your water supply!

The first player to plant a certain number of trees (depending on the number of players) wins the game.

name: Bolton Bonanza
description:
BOLTON BONANZA is one of a series of Monopoly style board game developed by local YMCAs in the UK to generate funds for their activities. The games in the series are essentially the same, but as in the different versions of Monopoly, the board and the businesses are specifically themed to the town or city represented in the title - in this case the City of BOLTON in the North-West of England.

Players progress around the board as a result of the roll of 2D6. When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company (there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

Players landing on companies that are already owned must pay to visit, with the payment due being based on how many shares are owned in that particular company and in the other two companies in the same colour series. Since shares can be owned by two different players both may demand payment from a visitor.

Certain squares on the board require the drawing of a Chance card which normally result in income being received from or paid to the bank.

The “New Share Quotations” square results in the changing of share prices for some of the blocks of companies. This will result in players losing or gaining money on the shares that they own. It also requires players to put up one of their shares for auction thereby permitting players to trade in shares.

The game can be ended in three ways, which should be decided before the game starts:
- After a set time.
- When the first player becomes bankrupt.
- When all but one player has gone bankrupt.

At the end of the game the money is counted and shares are valued at whatever is the then current rate. The player with the greatest assets is declared the winner.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Indian Arrow-Heads
description:
The game consists of 42 arrow-heads and a score card. The arrow-heads have a colored triangular head and a different colored tail into which another triangular head can fit. They also have a picture of an Indian with the name of a tribe (Potawatomi, Kiowa, Sioux, etc.) on the body, but for playing purpose, the tribes are irrelevant. The score card consists of jutting triangles of different colors and boxed numbers in 5 colors.
The arrow-heads are dealt out to players face down. Each player in turn places an arrow-head on either the score card or a previously played arrow-head so that the color of the head matches the color of the tail it fits into, thereby creating a box of one color. Players attempt to optimize their score by finding the match for their arrow-head that results in the largest available score on the score card. The score is recorded each time an arrow-head is played. If there is no available match for the player, he forfeits his turn, and must try again with the same arrow-head next turn.
Play continues until all arrow-heads have been played. The winner has the highest total.

name: Razoo: The Great Australian Game
description:
An hilarious race to get a Ute, Blue Heeler, BBq, and Footy Club Membership! Includes playing board and die, playing tokens, "Tassie Devil" "Raw Prawn" and Square Deal" cards other cards and play money.

Whether you're winning a chook raffle or the Melbourne Cup; buying a ute or a blue heeler; Joining a footy club or wrestling with a crocodile; or even tossing the coins to play Razoo-Up, it's Aussie fun for everyone
mechanics: Events, Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Track Movement

name: Half-board Chess
description:
This is Chess played on half of its usual board - 4 columns and 8 rows.

At the beginning there is a barrier between both 4x4 halves, and no player can look through it. The players are to arrange all the pieces any way they wish. When the board is full the barrier is removed.

The pieces move as in standard Chess but there are no special moves (double pawn move, castling en-passent). The pawn that reaches the last line promotes as usual. To win a player needs to checkmate or to stalemate (!) the other one. If there is a check at the beginning of the play the checked side loses. If both kings are checked at the beginning - there is a draw.

name: Toy Story 2 Cone Crossing Game
description: Based on the scene in Disney's "Toy Story" where Buzz Lightyear and company race across a busy road while hiding under traffic cones to rescue Woody. In this game designed for ages 4 and up you first roll a die to determine how many action points you get on a turn. Then you have three choices move the cones (you and your opponents cones are identical so you better remember which cones are yours). Or you may move obstacles to impede the path of your opponents. Or you may send the truck down the street (sending any cone it hits back to "GO").
categories: Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing

name: Oraïa
description:
The game is based in the 4 elements: water, air, earth and fire.
Each player choose one color and put his tokens in the starting places. Each player make alternate moves with his tokens.
The winner is the player who manage to move his tokens to the opponent's starting places.

Home Page: http://www.oraia.com/
publishers: Edition ABAX Jeux, M + A Spiele

name: Configurations
description: Player(s) work together to find an arrangement of digits in a table which satisfies certain criteria. Then they discover which of the image cards can be used to represent the table in diagrammatic form. More a puzzle than a game, and there's not much more to it once you "get it," but it does offer a glimpse into a backwater of Mathematics you might otherwise never have known about.

name: Solo Ball
description:
This baseball game aims to re-create the game of baseball without specifically duplicating the efforts of real-life Major League Baseball players. The owner of the game simply specifies a number of 'teams' for a league, and then plays out a number of contests to determine a winner. The 'teams' are simply a bunch of names, since players have no specific individual characteristics.

The game engine is a set of 100 cards with a series of play results on them. Results are situation specific; thus a play with one out will turn out differently depending on whether there are runners on 1st base, 2nd, 3rd, or none on. Each card also has two orientations, with a different set of play results on each side.

The game was marketed in conjunction with The Sporting News magazine. Included was an abbreviated version of TSN's booklet, "Batting And Pitching Averages At A Glance", which is designed to help the player figure out batting averages and other stats for his 'teams'.

name: The Maiden City Game
description:
THE MAIDEN CITY GAME is a Monopoly style board game developed by the Londonderry, Norther Ireland YMCA to generate funds for its activities.

Players progress around the board as a result of the roll of 2D6. When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company (there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

Players landing on companies that are already owned must pay to visit, with the payment due being based on how many shares are owned in that particular company and in the other two companies in the same colour series. Since shares can be owned by two different players both may demand payment from a visitor.

Certain squares on the board require the drawing of a Chance card which normally result in income being received from or paid to the bank.

The “New Share Quotations” square results in the changing of share prices for some of the blocks of companies. This will result in players losing or gaining money on the shares that they own. It also requires players to put up one of their shares for auction thereby permitting players to trade in shares.

The game can be ended in three ways, which should be decided before the game starts:
- After a set time.
- When the first player becomes bankrupt.
- When all but one player has gone bankrupt.

At the end of the game the money is counted and shares are valued at whatever is the then current rate. The player with the greatest assets is declared the winner.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Hossa!: Arbeiterlieder
description: An expansion for Hossa! which can also be played independently. This set of 53 cards features themes such as female workers, socialists, etc.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Music, Party Game

name: Clifford the Big Red Dog: Fetch a Bone
description: Each player plays a different-colored Clifford, the Big Red Dog. Each Clifford is trying to find the three bones that match their corresponding collar color (red, yellow, blue or green). On a player's turn, he presses down on the electronic Clifford doghouse, which will bark out the number of spaces to move in either direction (from one to three). He moves his Clifford and checks the bone beside the space he lands on see if it matches his collar color. If it does, he keeps the bone. First player to find all three of his bones wins.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Electronic, Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based, Racing

name: The Chelsea Flower Show Game
description: A game were players pretend to be a gardening experts visiting the major gardens and horticultural education centres of the UK collecting information and cards as they go. You also have to gain sponsorship before you can build your own garden, which may or not be effected by weather conditions and pests and may even receive a Royal Visit.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Set Collection

name: Hazard Cards
description:
Hazard Cards are created by researchers at the Danish research and development institution Learning Lab Denmark in cooperation with INCUBEus.

Hazard Cards is a card game about technological accidents.

Hazard Cards can be played like Top Trumps, Happy Families or whatever rules you make up for yourself. Apart from the printed information on each card, the website www.hazardcards.com contains a lot of additional information, links, data, resources, and texts about the characteristics of technologies and risk assessment theory.

name: Valvigi Downs
description:
From the back of the box

The game all America is talking about…

Valvigi Downs is America’s premier horse racing game, where anytime is post time. This exciting game combines the thrills of real horse racing with betting and poker strategies as well as the magic element of chance, to provide you with hours of fun and enjoyment. Play with family or friends. Create you own Triple Crown events. Players bet as much or as little as they like using play money. Whether a novice or a horse racing enthusiast, you’ll have a great time mastering actual betting techniques and horse racing terminology. Pick the long shots, the favorites or simply try to outsmart the odds. Let Valvigi Downs generate all of the excitement, anticipation, strategy and challenge of horse racing, poker and gamesmanship at its finest.

Let Valvigi Downs take you to the Winner’s Circle

name: Kleider machen Leute
description:
The game consists of 44 cards, 22 showing a head and 22 a hat belonging to the head.
The 22 pairs can form 11 couples, as there are a man and his wife (or a woman and her husband, if you like...)depicted on the cards (racing drivers, soldiers, cowboys etc.).
Every player gets a certain number of cards and tries to put together head and hat, and, if he's lucky enough, to melt the couple too.
This is done by picking up a card and discard. You can do that from the open discard pile or from the concealed reserve pile.
When the piles have been used up, you have to pass a card from your hand to your neíghbour. If he can form a pair, he is suspended from passing a card, next player in line has to proceed.
Game ends when all the pairs have been formed, every pair counting 1 point, every couple 5 points.

A light little family card game. The original Rudi Hoffmann graphics drawn by the maestro himself add to the atmosphere of the game.

name: Road Trip
description:
Roadtrip consists of 52 cards shaped lke license plates with vanity plates printed on them. One player is designated to flash the cards to the rest of the players, who are divided into two teams.

A card is flashed and the first team to shout out "Got it!" has five seconds to guess the translation of the vanity plate. If the first guess shouted is incorrect, the opposing team has five seconds to guess. A correct guess nets 5 point-miles and no guess or an incorrect guess is worth negative 2 point-miles.

The team with the most point miles after all the cards are flashed wins.

name: Meck Wars
description:
The Meck Wars book is a supplement for Injurius Games. You need Injurius Games to play Meck Wars.

After 5 years of arena battles, the ratings have gotten flat. The masses are getting restless, and the only thing Emperor Injurius will accept is a massive ratings sweep to bring the people back into the fold. A bright young ad executive at Mars Metals thinks of it first... Why not put Mecks in the Arena?

After the Meck War, which ended shortly before the League was formed, humanity swore they would never lose control of their machines again. These arena Mecks would be tightly controlled, highly programmed, and well sponsored by the huge corporations that Emperor Injurius had created to run the League.

After just one match, which put two squads of Mecks against each other, Emperor Injurius knew he had found a winner. The ratings were the highest ever recorded. Humanity had found its newest fad - Meck Wars!
..
.Summary from the back of the book:

It is the 22nd Century. After several years of successful gladiatorial games, Emperor Injurius has brought forth a new challenge, in the form of an old enemy, to increase the ratings of the arena battles.

Every gladiator who fights in the arena remembers this enemy. Every gladiator who dies for glory knows that it is a new battle. Every gladiator who hoped never to fight them again must face them one more time...

The Mecks have returned!

Salvaged from the battlefields of the Solar System, their metal and ceramic bodies re-built, their cold, calculating minds re-programmed, Mecks are the ultimate Corporate product.

They don't draw a salary, they take sponsorship without complaint, and they bring in the "underdog" viewer ratings that were sorely missing from recent human matches. The first Meck match was Meck vs Meck, but as their teams of programmers learned to refine their behavior, the Mecks were introduced against humans. Suddenly it was as if the Meck War had never ended.

You control a squad of five Mecks: the heavy Jumper leads from the front; a pair of middle-weight Spartans carries the firepower into battle; the light and fast Runners round out the team with speed only a Cheetah Suit's transmission could match.

Mecks earn Battle Honors the same way humans do, and can also gain software/power upgrades and hardware improvements. Their weapons are modular and may be switched from meck to Meck before any battle. Their command structure differs from human methods as well, owing to their networked nature. No distance to calculate for Command Points!

Meck Wars is not a stand-alone game. You need a copy of Injurius Games to play Meck Wars.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling

name: Serial Killer: The Board Game
description:
The game is packaged in a "body bag" and comes with several "body" counters.

It was banned in Canada and is probably one of the most deranged games ever created.

Players travel around a map of the United States killing people and attempting to only get caught in a state with no death penalty.

name: The Candy Bar Game
description:
A fun party game that allows you to win candy. The game is simple. There is enough candy for everyone participating to have at least 2 in the center of the gaming area. A die is rolled to determine the starting player. A timer is set for 10-15 minutes. Each person rolls 2 dice. With the roll of 7, 11 or doubles the roller chooses a candy either from the center untaken candies or from a person who has taken one. If that person does not have that specific candy that the roller asked then no candy changes hands. When the timer goes off the game is over and the candy you have is yours.

Post timer trading is always an option.

name: Le tour de Gaule d'Astérix
description:
"Liberate Lutetia and the other Gaulish towns from the Roman cohorts."

Le tour de Gaule d'Astérix is a simple roll the die and move game, in which players attempt to liberate towns as they move through Gaul.

The board consists of a round track superimposed on a map of Gaul. Lutetia and 19 other Gaulish towns are located at various spaces on the track. Each player starts with some money which they may use for equipping Gaulish armies. In turn, each player rolls the die and moves the indicated number of spaces along the circular track. If a player lands on an unliberated town, he or she may attempt to liberate it using their Gaulish armies.

name: Rings on Your Fingers
description: Children's memory game. Rings are placed upside-down on different coloured spaces. On each turn, the spinner determines what color spaces you are allowed to choose a ring from. If the ring you chose to look at matches your card, you may keep it. Players must find the five rings represented on their card.
publishers: MB Giochi, MB Jeux, Milton Bradley

name: Trilemma
description: A multi-level maths game to support the national numeracy strategy in an entertaining way. Trilemma tests the times tables and other mathematical functions non-sequentially. This challenging game of chance and skill can be played in a mixed age group with different players choosing different levels within the same game.

name: Zoboomafoo
description:
Box front:

What a wonderful party! Gather three animal friends and the foods they eat. Get them to the party first, and win the game! Fun for the entire family.

Box back:

You're invited to join Zoboo, the loveable lemur, and all his Animal Friends in Animal Junction! Travel around the colorful gameboard and look for the three animals that are on your special invitation card, plus a food that each of them likes to eat. After all, it's no party without snacks!

Children will have fun developing matching skills while learning what their favorite animals like to eat. The first player to get matching cards for all three animals on their card AND one yummy food card for each animal is the winner.

Ages 3 and up.
categories: Children's Game, Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Hocus Pocus
description:
Unusual game from Transogram that really relies on components which glow in the dark for gameplay mechanics. Comes in a very large box (17" x 12" x 8").

The game consists of a large hat with spring platform, four plastic rabbits (three of which glow in the dark), a large silk Hocus Pocus handkerchief, a wand with four detachable tips and many rings that are the game's 'currency' which also glow in the dark and must be worn on the fingers of players.

When a player has won enough rings during gameplay (they must be wearing 10 rings BEFORE their turn) they get the opportunity to insert the tip of the wand into the hat & release the spring, causing the rabbits to pop up in the air. This may or may not occur, depending on whether the correct wand tip is chosen.

The first player to make the rabbits fly out of the hat is the winner.

Although this game can be played in the light (by pretending the black rabbit is 'invisible') it is much more atmospheric and exciting in the dark.

name: The Wild-Flower Game
description:
From the box:
This game was developed to help you get to know and recognize some of the wild flowers that can be seen in Britain during the Spring and Summer. It should also make you aware that the future of even some quite familiar plants is now anything but secure in the wild.

Game Synopsis:
Roll the die and move along a numbered circular track. Gain points for landing on a colored circle; double them if you identify the associated wild flower. There are 'chance' cards, giving you extra points for answering wild-flower based questions.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Pitch-A-Story!
description:
THE GAME:

The PITCH-A-STORY! board gives you and your teammates a chance to create and act out stories during every turn in all kinds of places where story is king — film, TV, cartoons, literature, theater, and storytelling festivals.

OBJECT OF THE GAME:

To become a star by earning credits and review points awarded by your fellow players when you pitch stories using story elements from the game cards.

name: Hipp Hipp Hippo!
description:
The Hippo's are bathing. They like their privacy, and surround themselves with rocks and plants. They don't like crocodiles!

In this simple but fun kid's game, players draw and place cards around each other's Hippos. Plants score positive points, crocs negative.

name: Piggy Bank Card Game
description:
This card game is intended for 2 to 4 children ages 3 to 9. The game can be played three different ways.

1. PIGGY BANK: The entire deck is dealt to all players. Each turn a player turns over one card from his or her dealt pile. A card showing a nickel or five pennies is "banked". Other cards are placed in the center of the table in the "till". When a player draws a card that will match a card in the "till" to make five cents, those two cards are "banked". Cards can only be "banked" in two (or one) card combinations. The Silver Pig card is worth 10 cents -- two tricks. The player with the most money wins the game and becomes the next dealer.

2. DIME BANK: Plays like "Piggy Bank" except that players "bank" 10 cents instead of 5 cents, and the Silver Pig is worth 20 cents. (It is unclear how to avoid the two-card limit in this version.)

3. CONCENTRATION: This version is similar to the game card game Memory. It is for any number of players. Players "bank" pairs to add up to either 10 cents or 5 cents. A player's turn ends upon turning up the Silver Pig card. The game ends when there are two cards left, and a player uncovers a five-cent card and then the Silver Pig; this combination is worth two tricks.

name: Batman: The Chase Through Gotham City
description:
The eerie quietness of Gotham City has been shattered by the sound of the prison alarm. The Chase Through Gotham City has begun!

With the forces of good and evil racing to the hideout - who will win? Will one of the villains get to the hideout and go free or will one of the heroes get to the hideout first and block the entrance?

This game features glow in the dark game board, pieces, and spinner.

name: Kaleidomaze
description:
From Box:

"Kaleidomaze is a simple to play board game in a new dimension, which offers you the most unique experience of zigzagging through a maze - AN EVER CHANGING MAZE!

The object is to score from your opponents by taking over their BASEs and trapping their SUBJECT tokens in the maze with your STRESSOR peg. It sounds easy! But remember that your opponents are also trying their best to do the same - taking over your base and trapping you in the maze. Under these competitive conditions, the players manipulate the existing maze into a dynamic ever changing maze, that is KALEIDOMAZE.

As in life, very often you than CHANCEs (cards) for better or worse; and occasionally save one or two CREDITs (cards) to be used under certain adverse situations. Sometimes you may encounter such a dilemma of being trapped by your competitors; but fortunately many times you are able to develop intricate strategies and tactical moves to revert the embarrassment. Very often, your goal appears so close and yet it suddenly becomes so far. Many times, it appears so unlikely and yet it suddenly becomes so easy. This is KALEIDOMAZE.

You need strategy, judgment and luck to win the game. The rules are simple, and the skillfully designed gameboard and playing pieces allow you a wide choice of moves. This puzzling maze, being manipulated by you and your opponents, many times is very rewarding, but can also become a frustrating and aggravating challenge."

name: Antävlan
description:
Each player takes the role as a genealogist and your mission is to identify as many relatives as possible in 10 different families. You compete with limited resources and can build on your opponents' success or use their unused resources. Whoever has the most points when the last subscription appears wins.

The game came with a 16-day free trial (worth about 150 Swedish crowns, or $16) of Genline's internet database of more than 30 million Swedish church records in digitalised form.

name: Deduction
description: A game of logic and elimination played with a standard piecepack. Deduce the missing tile by asking the other players about what tiles they have hidden in their hands. The questions a player can ask are limited by the suit and number value on a drawn coin. Part of the game is inventing a effective way to record the information you have gained. This game is very similar to Sleuth by Sid Sackson.

name: Triple Flips 7: Great Adventures
description:
Triple Flips 7 includes Jungle Explorer, Dangers of the Deep, and Abominable Snowman Hunt.


Jungle Explorer is a roll-and-move game for 2-4 players, whose path becomes increasingly perilous as the pawns progress.



Dangers of the Deep is a 1-player game of risks, in which you attempt to take your bathyscaphe to as great a depth as possible. Each roll of the die has a 50% chance of increasing your risk. A 4 increases the undersea current, a 5 increases the water pressure (nicely depicted by drawings of a progressively crushed bathyscaphe), and a 6 reduces your remaining oxygen.



Abominable Snowman Hunt sets 2-4 players tracking the Abominable Snowman in an attempt to capture it.

name: Can-Doo
description:
PREPARATION:
Stack the cans in a pyramid. Shuffle all cards and place the deck face down, in easy reach of all players.

THE PLAY:
A player is chosen to be first. He takes a card from the card deck and now attempts to remove the matching can from the stack. He keeps the can and the card and the next player goes.

FALLING CANS:
If on a player's turn only one can drops from the stack, his turn is over and he must return the fallen can to the stack and the card to the bottom of the card deck. He scores no points for that round. If more than one can drops from the stack, the game is over and the player who upsets the stack scores no points for that round.

WINNING THE GAME:
Each player counts the total point score of his cards. Highest point score wins the game.

name: Freeze
description:
An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

Player 1 owns the black checkers, while player 2 owns the red checkers. Opponents alternate turns, as in most games. A 'king' is defined as in the game of Checkers: it is a stack of two checkers, of the same color. Kings cannot move but can be captured.

On his turn, a player chooses one of his own checkers to move. Moves are made vertically or horizontally, but not diagonally. A single move consists of picking up the chosen checker, jumping it over an opponent's checker or king (the jumped checker or king must be directly above, below, left, or right of the moving checker), and landing on an unoccupied square on the other side of the jumped checker. The jumped checker or king is then captured (removed from the board). On the same turn, a player may (but is not required to) continue moving this chosen checker in this way, until that checker cannot capture any more. A checker can only move if in so doing it captures an opponent's checker or king.

On his turn, after he has finished capturing, a player may use the checkers which he has just captured to transform some of his opponent's checkers into kings, by placing a single captured checker on top of a checker of the same color which is still on the board. The two checkers from a captured king can be used to make two new kings. A player can make as many kings on his turn as he has captured checkers.

The loser is the first player not able to move on his turn.

name: Monopoly: U.S. Space Program
description: This is a US Space Program flavored version of the classic board game. It comes with 8 customized tokens (satellite, astronaut, shuttle, lunar rover, space capsule, lunar lander, the Hubble, or the Mars Sojourner), a board with space program related destinations, hangars and space centers instead of houses and hotels, and Moon and Earth cards. It also features a complete mission manual with additional information on the US Space Program.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Tournée Générale
description:
The most refreshing game you've ever tasted
Tournée Générale is a quiz game about Belgian beers.

name: Scavenger Hunt
description:
A game for a standard piecepack.

Move around a ever changing board trying to collect your six coins before the other players. The game has strong memory element.

name: Gobbler
description:
One player controls two "gobblers" who are attempting to eat as many of the other player's sixty "littles" as possible before they scurry out of their reach.

Any number of littles may occupy a space on an 8x8 board and they will automatically disperse one space away from a gobbler when it lands on an adjacent space. A gobbler makes two Chess-knight moves on its turn and any number of littles may move one space on their turn.

name: Domino Road
description:
From the box front:

These wooden pieces are an early introduction to Dominoes. As players match roadways and vehicles their Thinking and Problem solving skills are stimulated with yet another dimension in discovery! The player who is able to properly place all of his or her pieces first wins!

From the box back:

Domino Road is a wonderful addition to the discovery Toys Thinking and Problem solving Preschool line. Your child will first want to assemble his or her roadway like a puzzle. But DOMINO ROAD has a puzzling twist; preschoolers must match roadways and vehicles! This wonderful stimulating puzzle will capture their attention for hours!

Summary:

Wooden tiles showing roads and 3-dimensional vehicles. most tile edges show 1/2 of a vehicle which matches up to other tiles' 1/2 vehicles when placed adjacent. Vehicles are in several colors and styles.
mechanics: Modular Board, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement

name: Naughty Checkers
description:
From the Box:

"The Interactive Game where 'Checking your Mate' takes on a whole new meaning."

This is checkers, but with a difference.

The (inner) dark squares have instructions on them, such as "Show your undies", "Kiss my neck", "Run your lips up and down my arm". Whenever a piece is captured, the action exposed by the removed piece must be performed by the opponent.

The back row squares (where kings are crowned) have juicier instructions on them, such as "Kiss my inner thigh", "Lick the word 'love' on my tummy", "Divulge a secret fantasy". Whenever a king is crowned, the opponent must carry out the instruction printed on the square where the king stands.

The winner is the first person to capture all his/her opponent's checkers or makes it impossible for his/her opponent to make a move.

name: Jetzt kommt Jasper!
description: Jasper the penguin (from German TV-show "Sendung mit der Maus") tries to get around the town with help of his friend Emma. Whoever answers the most questions and gets to the end of the city, wins. 36 Cards, 36 quiz cards, 8 pawns, 2 dice, 1 board, rules; 5 years and up; Nürnberg 2006.

name: The Dale Carnegie Game
description: Based on the best-selling book "How To Win Friends and Influence People", this game teaches the principals of the book and helps players develop more dynamic interpersonal skills.

name: Battle of Manila
description:
A very early Parker Brothers game (often mentioned in histories of the company),
Battle of Manila is a Spanish American War boardgame with chromolithographed box lid and board with Manila Bay, 15.5" x 19.5" x 2" high.

Unlike today's heavily detailed "conflict simulations", this game apparently mainly involved hitting soldier targets on a board with hand held cannons firing wooden "bullets".

This game did help cement Parker Bros. reputation as a patriotic American company, helping sales and its image with the American public.

name: Big Damn Armies
description: Part of the "Big Damn" line from Crunchy Frog, Big Damn Armies is a fantasy battle game. The rules are very simple, presented on single-sided photocopied sheets. Card stock miniatures with unit stats printed on them are included.

name: Sumitup
description:
Maths Scrabble - put tiles on the board to make simple maths equations (like 3+6=9, 2x5=10 etc), score points based on the tiles used.

Ages 4 and up

From the Box:
Sumitup - The board game that makes numbers fun!

Contents: 134 Tiles in a Cloth Bag; Playing Board; 4 Tile Holders; Rule Book

name: Watson's Education
description:
This is based on my older game Watson's Bible Inquest (Biblical characters have been replaced with historical figures). It is a game of deduction where players draw cards and must deduce which historical figures are in the opponents hands based on a set of questions. Points are awarded for correct guesses and points given to the opponents for incorrect guesses. The game is scalable for different age groups or experience. It is also educational, although this aspect is not necessary (players may use the charts provided with the game instead).

It is available for free download (Print and Play) at my web site:

http://www.tzon.org/watson.htm

Points are awarded for correct guesses and points given to the opponents for incorrect guesses. The game is scalable for different age groups or experience. name: Age of Battles: Sekigahara 1600
description:
Sekigahara 1600 is part of the Age Of Battles table-top miniatures gaming system using 1/72 scale miniatures and the Shogun rule set. Sekigahara 1600 allows you to play the battle over four scenarios:

1. First Clashes
2. Red Devils Attack
3. Kobayakawa Choice
4. Shimadzu Clan Breakthrough

The boxed game set includes everything needed to play out Sekigahara 1600:

88 Samurai Infantry - tan/grey (two sets of ZV 8017)
51 Samurai Cavalry - tan/grey/red (three sets of ZV 8025)
20 Regiment Stands
12 Modular Plastic Trees w/stands
16 Laminated Regiment Cards
1 Pen
2 Rulers
1 Angle Pattern
1 Shogun Rule Book
1 Historical Description Booklet w/battle scenarios and unit tables

From the back of the box:
The military historical game "The Battle of Sakigahara" is based on the fight that took place in the plain near a Japanese village called Sakigahara. Here October 21, 1600 two samurai armies, more than 80,000 people each, met in the bloody battle. Tokugava Leyasu, an experienced general and politician, profited from the treason in the ranks of the enemy and defeated its troops thus stopping endless wars and establishing his shogunate in Japan.

This game is for 2-6 players. The enemy armies led by the players meet in the plain between mountains. Tactic maneuverings are very important in the game. Under a skillful leader a smaller army can defeat an outnumbering enemy. You can either recreate the historic battle or change the course of the fight. Anyway you should rely not only on the number of your army but also on your leadership and war skills.

Zvezda 8224
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Whirl Out
description:
In Whirl Out, luck and skill both come into play as players try to keep their marbles on the whirling wheel.

During the game, players spin to determine into which section of the 3-D wheel they must place one of their colored marbles. After the marble is placed into one of the marble holders on the wheel, the wheel will turn under the weight of the marble and will eventually come to a stop. The next player proceeds in the same way.

When the wheel rotates, some marbles may fall through the back of the wheel and down a marble return chute and into the return well, where the marbles are picked up by their respective players to be placed again, in turn.

If a player spins "Wipe Out" on the spinner, they place the steel ball in one of the empty marble holders. The weight of the steel ball can whirl the wheel back and forth several times before it comes to rest.

Players continue, in turn, to place their marbles on the wheel. When one player successfully places all of their marbles--and the wheel is at rest--that player wins the game.

name: Early Discoveries
description:
Four children's games in one box.

What's for Lunch - Teaches children to identify five colors and shapes and four different animals.

Construction Crew - Children learn to identify geometric shapes without the aid of color.

Hurry Home - Teaches children the identification of people, places and occupations in a typical community and the objects normally associated with them.

Animal Galore - Children are introduced to simple strategy and use one to one correspondence to identity various animals.
mechanics: Chit-Pull System, Cooperative Game, Pattern Recognition, Roll / Spin and Move, Tile Placement

name: Kabouterstad
description:
Together the gnomes build a new village. They make houses with wooden stones in several colors. The die indicates in which color the next stone can be laid. But watch out for blue! That is the color of the kobold. And this small game spoiler makes his own blue tower which can fall at any moment and destroy the houses of the gnomes. The tension rises... who is fastest? The kind gnomes or the naughty kobold?

Kabouterstad (Gnome City) is a game where cooperation has been required and in which the players must help each other to finish the gnome city before the kobold builds his own blue tower.
The playing cards are printed on both sides. On the front a construction stands which must be reconstructed exactly. With the figure on the back we leave the fantasy of the children.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Pattern Building

name: Legendary Battles
description:
Rules for using 25mm or 15mm miniatures to play Fantasy battles. Highlights include an extremely accurate point system for creating armies, streamlined rules with no exceptions or special cases, no die roll modifiers, and a movement stand system that combines the simplicity of stand-based movement (like DBA) with the detail of figure based combat (like Warhammer).

The expansion, Advanced Legendary Battles, adds Magic and Monsters, but is not as well edited or play tested.

name: Poetryslam Magnetic Word Game
description:
Martin Smith created POETRYSLAM MAGNETIC WORD GAME to experiment with language, poetry, and humor. It combines magnetic poetry with the concept of poetry slams and a 12x24 (magnetic) gameboard.

The game's word tiles will be familiar to anyone who knows magnetic poetry. There are nouns, verbs, adjectives, and endings. A miscellaneous category includes adverbs, conjunctions, pronouns, and prepositions. A rating assigned to each word reflects the difficulty of using that word in the magnetic poetry slam (1=easy; 8=obscure word) and doubles as the scoring mechanism.

Each player creates a line or a poem up to six words in length each turn. Second and subsequent lines/poems must include at least one word from those already on the board. The sum of the difficulty rating determines the score for the line or poem. The magnetic grid includes bonus cells, which add points to the play.

name: The OC Game
description: A trivia game based on the Fox network show "The OC"
